pros:
- close-knit community : because office teams are small, colleagues easily become friends. This is a great source of positivity, especially when you have relocated to a new country to work.
- opportunities to learn : the associate role is a great space for anyone wanting to learn more about data and international development. There are many impressive individuals in the org who you can learn a lot from. 
- true to its mission : as far as possible, IDi does try to achieve social impact.
- growing organization : although this has its downsides, it means there can be more opportunities for growth and that the organization is willing to learn and do better.
cons:

review_title: Overall excellent, but has opportunities to improve
pros: The org has an amazing, mission, approach, and opportunity to put diverse professional skills towards meaningful and interesting problems. You can grow and increase responsibility quickly if you're able to raise to the challenges. You have the opportunity to work with some amazing clients doing super important work in the world. The value the org provides to partner organizations can be (but is not always) extremely high-leverage, and you have the opportunity to have a lot of personal impact. The org seems to have made a lot of progress in the last years towards creating a more locally-centred organisation, though they have continued room to improve.
cons: Project work can vary a lot, so you need to be willing to be flexible and willing to look for opportunity in a lot of different situations if you want to thrive. Balancing and values across contexts and geographies has been hard, and they don't always get it right the first time. They are definitely interested in figuring out how to do this better, but still have room to grow.

review_title: Incredible people | mission that matters | great organization
pros:
IDinsight is filled with some of the best people working in international development. The team is incredibly smart, caring, collaborative, and kind. 

In addition, the organization genuinely cares about achieving impact. Instead of just paying lip service to working on projects that matter, IDinsight actually cultivates a portfolio based on their best guesses of what will improve the human condition. 

Finally, IDinsight invests in internal systems and creating a wonderful working environment. While the work can sometimes be demanding, I always felt that the organization genuinely cared about me and was building great systems with the goal of retaining talent and creating a great place to work, all in the pursuit of social impact.
cons: IDinsight is still relatively small. While the organization is well known in certain circles, there are many people that do not know of IDinsight, which can be a downside. Let's put it like this, your grandparents are likely to say "ID what's it again?" many times over the course of your time with the team.

review_title: Amazing colleagues and great opportunities for growth
pros:
I thoroughly enjoyed my tenure with IDinsight. I've never before worked somewhere that has so many genuinely nice people. Caring, engaged, smart colleagues is one of the things I'll miss the most about IDinsight -- I learned so much from getting to work across so many teams and geographies. 

Some additional pros:

- Opportunity to work across wide range of topics, sectors, evaluation types, geographies, and teams.
- Engaged and responsive senior management team.
- Team-based project work and lots of direct client interaction.
- Supportive colleagues who care about how you are doing.
- Decent amount of independence to pursue impactful work.
cons:
Not necessarily 'cons' but points to consider when weighing if the role is right for you: 

- It is a global organization and thus you often need to be flexible on schedules in order to meet teammates across time zones.
- IDinsight is impact-first in its work and thus the entire organization goes above and beyond trying to over-deliver to clients in the pursuit of social impact. This means work can ebb and flow and that is not a 9-5 job.
- Teammates are challenged in their work and there is a lot of opportunity for growth. At the same time, given the fast-paced nature of work, there is not always a lot of time for hand-holding. The org is continuing to invest in formal PD, but being self-directed in learning is also important.

pros: A lot of development organizations take their employees for granted, because they know that mission and passion drive people working in the sector. IDinsight is different, because it takes care of its people. It knows that while we're ultimately working to make the world a better place, it shouldn't be at our own expense.
cons: In some ways, IDinsight is too keen on expanding in new areas. I feel like the organization always wants to be ahead and, in some ways, feeds into the idea that development projects are a competition.

review_title: Great team and org values; need to improve work-life balance
pros:
Hands down, one of the best things about IDinsight are its people: exceptional colleagues who are very bright but also humble and relatable. The organization encourages curiosity and debate, which means that there is always an abundance of thoughtful discussions about international development, statistics, or life in general. It is definitely a great place to learn. 

Partners are candid and transparent, and aim to be inclusive in decisions involving the organization at large. 

The global operations team is standardizing the staff performance review process so there is a push towards more clarity on how you are performing in your role, and how promotions are obtained.
cons:
Work-life balance is a challenge: travel schedules can be abrupt, requiring staff to travel or relocate on a very short notice (like in a week or a day), which can be disruptive. The pace of the job varies depending on phases of the project, but fieldwork in rural areas is often fast-paced and can result in 10-12 hour days. An individual's experience can also vary significantly depending on the type of project they are staffed on and their particular manager / supervisor's style of management. 

Finally, salary and benefits are comparable to other non-profit roles based abroad; however, salaries would be better adjusted to years of experience.

review_title: Rigorous, meaningful work with high professional standards
pros:
I feel really lucky to have found a professional home at IDinsight. To me, the organization offers a unique combination of rigorous, meaningful work and high professional standards. My favorite parts of the job:

- Genuine commitment to impact. I'm constantly surprised and impressed by the emphasis put on improving the world, over and above things like getting good publicity or a more lucrative contract. 

- Opportunities for skill development. This can be easy to lose sight of during a project crunch when all you're doing is writing a report or cleaning data, but in the time I've been at IDinsight I've learned so much. I've gotten to build on existing skills, like writing and using Stata for data analysis; and add many new ones, like public speaking, client management, people management, large-scale data collection, SurveyCTO, etc. When and if I move on to another job, I know I'm much better prepared than I was when I started.

- Amazing colleagues. When I catch up with old classmates I often hear about how much they miss the intellectual stimulation of being at university and getting to engage in high-level debates about politics, ethics, and how to make the world a better place. I actually _don't_ miss that, because IDinsighters are an incredible group of people! I think that's partly due to (self) selection, and partly due to opportunities the organization creates to encourage interesting exchanges and build relationships. We often take time out of busy days to hear from a guest speaker or discuss an interesting new paper. Most importantly, people are kind and hardworking. Although people come in with a range of opinions and experiences, there's a common thread of sincerity and dedication that I really value. I know I could message just about anyone in the organization with a question or request and they'd take time out of their day to help out.

- The range of opportunities available to IDinsighters at all levels and positions. I've personally benefitted from being trusted with a lot of responsibility early on, and also just enjoy being part of an organization that provides those opportunities to others: from an Associate presenting evaluation results to a high-level government official, to Field Managers running trainings on SurveyCTO for incoming Managers & Directors, to Economists spending weeks on location with a project to pitch in. At the rate we're growing, there are also lots of exciting (albeit sometimes unpredictable) opportunities for professional growth. I know a number of people who have carved out fulfilling roles for themselves by matching their own skills and interests to a newly identified organizational need.

- The clients! I know that might sound trite but I'm completely sincere. By and large, we do a great job of selecting inspiring, impactful organizations to work with. I feel incredibly fortunate knowing that if I do my job well, I can help our clients better serve poor and marginalized communities.
cons:
From my perspective, the biggest potential downsides of working here are:

- High levels of independence can sometimes feel like a lack of support. IDinsight has taken positive steps to mitigate that (for example, every employee has an 'advisor' who's senior to them and a 'buddy' who's a peer, in addition to their direct supervisor; there are regular 'team health checks' and other opportunities to give upward feedback), but I know it can be tough at times for people who are in remote offices or have a supervisor who's based elsewhere. That level of independence and responsibility is exciting for some people and stressful for others, and I think it's wise to be thoughtful about which camp you might fall in before taking a job here.

- A lot depends on your project. Managers and Directors are more likely to work on multiple projects, but Associates generally work on just one project at a time and may be on a single project for their first 1-2 years with IDinsight. On the one hand, this staffing model allows Associates to develop expertise on that project and engage in a deeper way with the sector and client. The pace of most IDinsight projects also means that over the course of two years most Associates will get exposure to all project phases (client development, evaluation design, fieldwork, analysis, report writing, etc, not necessarily in that order). On the other hand, this means there's some luck involved in whether and when you get to work on a particular sector/client type/methodology. If you're at the beginning of your career and already have very specific goals (e.g. you're passionate about health and only want to work on that type of project; or you already know you're applying to econ PhDs and absolutely must work on an RCT in your first six months) then I'd recommend looking for a job with a narrower focus.

review_title: Ideal entry-level position for ambitious, social impact-minded people
pros:
– Smart, passionate, and hard-working colleagues
– Ideal entry-level positions – Associates are given a lot of autonomy (when shown ready) and are the ones driving projects. The Associate role allows you to develop a diversity of skills, including technical skills (evaluation design; data collection, cleaning, and analysis, etc.) and social skills (client relationships, management during fieldwork, etc.)
– Diversity across all levels of hierarchy (as, in fact, everybody can see on the website)
– Transparent 360° performance review in place – providing detailed feedback on areas of improvement and informing promotion decisions 
– Impact first – informing everything from project selection to hiring. Make an argument on how IDinsight could increase its social impact and you will always be heard.
– Clear focus on performance rather than input – generally, managers don’t care too much about how you do your work as long as you deliver good quality efficiently.
– IDinsight is growingly rapidly, thus there are still a lot of opportunities to shape how the organization is operating.
– Organization values your professional development – you are encouraged to write and follow a professional development plan and make time for it during workweek.
cons:
– Not the right place for you if you require close supervision to thrive; sometimes not as close mentorship as you would see for example in management consulting (depends on the project though), but you will receive guidance and support if you’re asking for it.
– Not the right place for if you’re semi-sure about your commitment to impact – must be willing to take up with extended stays in rural areas and sometimes long hours.
– Strategic communications and IDinsight brand still relatively poor outside the social sector – this may affect your exit options if you want to leave the social/development sector after IDinsight (but most Associates either stay in the social/development sector or go to grad school, for which it is great).

review_title: Incredible development org that shaped me and my career
pros:
- Your colleagues will be some of the smartest, kindest, most thoughtful, reflective and generous people you've ever met.
- IDinsight is laser-focused on impact in a way that's rare and refreshing. Over four years in the org at different levels, I saw projects being turned down repeatedly that would've been good for prestige, funding, or client relationships, but were lacking in being demand-driven and high-potential for impact. It is exceedingly rare to find an organisation in international development as willing to put its money where its mouth is on its values and concern for social impact.
- Staying focused on impact requires operational flexibility; IDinsight is committed to this. When you work in development you realise how deviously difficult and uncertain it is to create meaningful, lasting change in social programs and institutional structures. Your best shot at this is to remain flexible in service-type, team structure, role etc. This creates organisational uncertainty, but there is no doing away with this if you want to hold onto the nimbleness that creating impact requires.
- IDinsight is truly a learning organisation. They shine the measurement and learning light back on themselves and are committed to measuring org impact. This is again rare and refreshing in the field.
- They strive to create a space where it's the best idea that wins the day, not the loudest (or most senior) voice. I came in at 21 and was able to speak to everyone, Partner and onward, in a flat and equal setting. This is certainly not the culture of other organisations in most countries where IDinsight operates.

NB: I'm *very* surprised to see some of the negative reviews on here. In my (4-year) experience at IDinsight, these reviews reflect more specific types of personalities that are prone to complain v/s fix and would have a hard time wherever they go.
cons:
- Since the organisation was founded by 4 American HKS/HBS grads (although 3 of 4 are mixed-identity Americans) for a while there was an overhang of that background in hiring. Employees came largely from elite, American universities which leads to an American bias in internal culture. However, I think the org recognised this, and has done a lot to diversify recruitment (for example, having clear targets that the majority of staff in project offices should be nationals of the country, diversifying recruitment towards local universities).
- If you want to work a fixed 9-5 schedule, then this is not the right place for you.
- Also agree with others' advice that if you are an incoming Associate inflexible on sector or project-type, then it is not likely to be a great fit both-ways.

pros:
Culture is a crucial part of what makes IDinsight a great place to work. Leaders emphasize autonomy, ownership, and purpose. IDinsight values (including humility, honesty, impact, and service) are not just lip-service...they permeate everything from global summit agendas to performance reviews. Partners are bullishly focused on impact. They are honest about where we could improve -- it's a culture based on data and transparency, not hand-waving and self-congratulatory back-patting. Our CEO has a strong and clear vision, and a great talent for getting others on board with that vision. IDinsight's mission is nothing short of changing the way the world thinks about using evidence to serve the poor, and redirecting billions of dollars towards the most effective programs. In five short years, the org has expanded 20-fold and started some exciting collaborations with big market-makers like GiveWell.

Everyone from Field Managers to Associates to Directors and Partners have an incredible amount of responsibility on projects. Fresh-out-of-college grads get a chance to manage teams and make important project decisions, lead client meetings, etc. Professional development opportunities are unparalleled for the sector.

Promotions happen quickly and frequently compared to almost any other benchmark (average length between roles is 1-2 years), and are merit-based and quite transparent given the newly revamped performance review process.

It is exciting to be part of such a fast-growing and ambitious organization, that also invests heavily in its people and in being data-driven and well-run internally.
cons:
Given that we are a measurement organization, it can be hard to rigorously assess our own impact as a consultancy/evaluator. We are trying.

Moving toward an embedded Learning Partnership client model has its challenges. It allows teams to work more closely with clients and meet their needs, but also means some IDinsight teams are remotely embedded and it can be harder to set clear project boundaries.

review_title: Great company in the development sector at a key inflection point
pros: Fantastic colleagues who are intellectually curious and committed to development. Projects are becoming increasingly interesting as IDinsight continues to grow and the brand becomes stronger in the sector. The new CEO has a ton of experience and is poised to make IDinsight better known. Huge emphasis on feedback and professional development. Relatively strong operations team, which is somewhat unheard of in the development space. Overall, the company cares about and values employees. I think IDinsight is fantastic and I really want to see it suceed.
cons: Not enough discussions about the ethical issues raised when IDinsight works with morally questionable governments. While we have a hard-working operations team, there is a danger that the company can become too process-oriented and overly bureaucratic. Unclear how socially impactful some projects are (some just sound fancy, like sending crypto-currency to x population, but where is the impact?). We still haven't figure out a sustainable life-work balance at all levels, including Directors. IDinsight is still very timid in terms of external communications for fear of not appearing rigorous enough in front of the economics academic establishment.

review_title: Great job to build development experience; some fundamental issues with the org.
pros:
•	The biggest ‘pro’ at IDinsight is the people. Young, eager, very smart, friendly, and hard-working. You’ll almost never find someone unwilling to help you, or hear “that’s not my problem.” IDinsight is fun place to work because of the people.
•	Unique vision and mission that the development sector desperately needs (but unfortunately, rarely wants). You won’t find many other organizations trying to do what IDinsight is trying to do. Also, IDinsight is willing to change its tactics to adapt to what they think will be more effective, or to what they think the sector wants.
•	Quite flexible with office work schedules. No one will be counting your hours unless you’re under-performing. Very generous with work remote options (mostly a “common sense” or “best judgment” policy, as with many other policies at IDinsight). 
•	(Expat only) You’ll gain valuable overseas experience you can market to your next job. There’s a good chance you won’t be located in the same country (if Africa) or state (if India) as your project, but it looks better for you in the development sector job market than working from the US or Europe.
•	You’ll work with some name-brand clients, and establish a robust professional network.
•	You will learn *a lot* (sector knowledge, coding, field work, managing projects, working with people, working with clients, so on).
•	Everyone receives formal, 360 degree performance evaluations (2 per year). Associates receive lots of on-the-spot feedback.
•	IDinsight is best experienced as an associate, as long as you are undoubtedly committed the sector, know what it means to work hard (occasional 70-hour weeks), and patient with the organization as it finds its way and grows. Fantastic entry-level job in the development sector.
cons:
•	Most fundamental ‘con’: the vast majority of projects do not live up to what IDinsight says it’s doing. They’re not demand driven, they’re only sometimes informing relatively minor decisions, and they do not achieve tangible impact (but IDinsight will often attribute impact to themselves based on weak assumptions, which seems contradictory for an evaluation firm…). For every success story you hear about, there are 10 more fundamentally broken projects with no path to impact (you’ll notice that you’ll hear about the same success stories over and over again because i] there are so few and ii] there’s very little external communication).
•	IDinsight is willing to adapt its strategy (pro), but that also means they’re constantly experimenting with their services. As a result, they’ll regularly commit to unfamiliar work, work without clear objectives, or work with uncertain paths to impact.
•	IDinsight regularly selects projects based on factors other than social impact: maintain/creating client relationships, funding, or other “strategic” reasons.
•	Your experience as an associate (and your perception of IDinsight in general) is highly dependent on the project you’re assigned to (the amount of field work vs. quantitative/coding vs. client-facing time vs. writing); and there’s no guarantee you’ll get the project you want or like. Some get lucky, others don’t. You’ll do best if you don’t care and you’re just willing to learn as much as possible.
•	The pipeline of new projects naturally does not align with the pipeline of new hires. IDinsight tends to hire in cohorts, but takes on projects continuously. You’ll won’t a project waiting for you when you’re hired. *As a new associate, you can easily go your first 3-6 months without a project.* 
•	Everyone is young, which also means inexperienced. This is expected for associates, but it’s an issue with leadership.
•	(Expats only) Not very diverse in terms of socioeconomic backgrounds.
•	Young organization is not without growing pains. IDinsight hasn’t figured out or not yet addressed things you can take as given in organizations that have been around longer. 
•	Almost nonexistent external communications (they’re working on it. re: young organization)
•	Knowledge management isn’t great (again, they’re working on it). Project teams continuously reinvent the wheel. Low staff retention doesn’t help either.
•	Low salaries and a poor (in-house, ultimately black box) method to calculate cost of living across country offices.

pros:
•	Tech Stipend – you are provided with a reasonable technology budget, which gives you the freedom to choose your preferred equipment. 
•	Good opportunity to gain initial experience in the sector – For those with limited experience, the associate role offers a good opportunity to get an initial insight into the sector. 
•	Flexibility to work from home – Relatively flexible approach to working from home, depending on your manager.
cons:
•	Inequality across job titles – There is a large range of experience and education within the same job title. It is not uncommon to find individuals with 3-6 months experience and an undergraduate degree in the same position as individuals with 3 years’ experience and a postgraduate degree. Furthermore, in some cases staff in senior positions had less relevant experience or education than staff they were managing. This was often disaggregated across local and ex-pat staff, with the former requiring more experience and education for the same position.
•	Progress and opportunities based on popularity with leadership – Leaderships opinion carries more weight than performance on the opportunities and progress in the organisation. Well liked individuals gain opportunity to projects that allow them to fulfil criteria for promotion and are typically promoted quicker promotions. 
•	Penalty for speaking out or voicing differing opinion – Individuals who speak out or make suggestions counter to leaderships opinions are often labelled a bad fit or even a threat to the organization. Likewise, leadership often take feedback personally, despite staff being encouraged to provide frequent upwards feedback.
•	Lack of diversity among senior staff – There are very few local staff in management positions. Furthermore, leadership would often cite a lack of skilled individuals in local countries as the reasoning. 
•	Projects often have very diluted impact – Projects are often very far removed from impact, and this can be demotivating if you are keen to see the direct impact of your work. The organization also struggles to have much influence within the sector due to its unwillingness to engage with a broader range of clients. 
•	Inconsistent strategy and slow to adapt rest of organization to changes – The overall strategy of the organization feels unclear. Originally there was a large focus on demand driven impact evaluations, which then shifted to learning partnerships. It feels as if the organization isn’t clear on its role or expertise in the sector. This is also reflected in its hiring and promotion criteria, which is heavily focused on skills required for impact evaluations, despite a shift towards more learning partnerships.
